fields.title: Tips for Buying a Classical Instrument
fields.post:
1. Bring a friend/pro
    Having a second opinion is very important when buying an instrument and it always helps if the person is either a professional or good amateur. They can listen while you play and visa-versa. Asking your instrumental teacher to come along is never a bad idea.
  2. Do your homework
    Find out as much as you can about the instrument by using Google and asking your teacher/friends. Try to find out what the average selling price is for the instrument you are interested in.
  3. Test the instrument properly
    Make sure you have a plan before you visit, this means deciding on what you will play on the instrument when you test it out. Making sure the repertoire is varied is important.
  4. Haggle
    If you have seen the same instrument in the same condition selling for less, then write down where and take it along and show the seller. Perhaps they won’t reduce the price but it is worth a try.
  5. Written proof of purchase
    Anything officially proving purchase, including certificates, receipts etc… is preferred
  6. Decide on the most important things that you’re looking for
    Knowing what you want from your next instrument is important, because it allows you to focus on searching for those requirements, rather than having too wide a scope.
  7. Start with a budget
    Deciding on how much you have to spend will again help in focusing more acutely on the vast amount of good instruments that are available.
  8. Value for money
    Is the instrument a bargain? If not then it’s perhaps better to continue searching.
  9. Insure the instrument
    Once you have decided to take the plunge and invest a lot of money into your instrument, then don’t forget to insure it just in case anything bad does happen.
  10. Get the full details of the instrument
    Ask the seller as much as possible about the instrument they are selling. Ask them why they are selling and ask them to play on the instrument. What do they like/dislike about the instrument?
  11. Don’t buy if uncertain
    If you have doubts then don’t buy immediately. If need be, visit the seller again and test the instrument again until you are confident that it is the right decision. Don’t forget that, thanks to the internet, the choice available to musicians is much larger than it has ever been.
